meaning_mnemonic: Who's someone who's just a <radical>mouth</radical> with <radical>legs</radical>? That's your know-it-all <kanji>older brother</kanji>, who won't shut up about anything.

The <radical>leader</radical> for the <radical>ceremony</radical> can't come so you need a <kanji>substitute</kanji> to <kanji>replace</kanji> them ASAP!

This kanji has another meaning too. The leader can't come to the ceremony because they forgot what <kanji>period</kanji> of time it was. If they think they're in the wrong <kanji>age</kanji>, they won't come because they're trying to lead some monkeys in the ceremony instead.

You go down a <radical>slide</radical> made of <radical>branch</radical>es and your <kanji>skin</kanji> scrapes right off — ouch! Lucky for you, it was just your old outer layer of skin, and now you've got a fresh shiny layer. Yay for exfoliation! You're not sure what to do with this big, floppy layer of old skin, though…

You put a <radical>lid</radical> on your <radical>father</radical>. But, he won't taste good alone, so you <kanji>mix</kanji> in some other ingredients. They <kanji>mingle</kanji> inside the pot with him.
The <radical>meet</radical> radical and the <kanji>meet</kanji> kanji are the same!

You see a <radical>triceratops</radical> in the distance. But, it's odd. It's perfectly <radical>pi</radical> shaped (that is, circular, like a pie). Some kind of piceratops, if you will. The reason they are this shape is because they want to absorb as much <kanji>light</kanji> as possible. They evolved to be round so they don't have any corners casting a shadow.
There's a <radical>mustache</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical>. Upon closer inspection, you see that the mustache on the ground is exactly the <kanji>same</kanji> as yours!

There's a <radical>mouth</radical> inside a <radical>mouth</radical>. But if you look even closer (not actually, but we're pretending), you can see another mouth inside that mouth... and another one inside of that one! It keeps going and going. Can you count the number of <kanji>times</kanji> there's a mouth inside a mouth? This kanji also means <kanji>revolve</kanji> too. Think of each "time" a thing happens, it loops back around and comes back to the beginning, revolving around again another time.
How many <radical>evenings</radical> are there? There are <kanji>many</kanji>.

What superhero is most like a <radical>triceratops</radical>? …If you said <radical>Wolverine</radical>, you're <kanji>correct</kanji>! Why is that the <kanji>right</kanji> answer? Because the triceratops has three horns, and Wolverine has three blades coming out of his hands. It's obvious, isn't it? But you knew that of course.

You have a <radical>gun</radical> and you see some <radical>windows</radical>. What do you think you're going to do with this gun? Of course, you're going to shoot the windows... <kanji>every</kanji> single one of them. <kanji>Each</kanji> and every one.

The <radical>rice</radical> radical and <kanji>rice</kanji> kanji are the same in looks and meaning. This kanji can also mean <kanji>America</kanji>, maybe because America is covered in rice or fields or something?
The <radical>feathers</radical> radical and <kanji>feather</kanji> kanji are the same in looks as well as in meaning.

In a <radical>coffin</radical> there's a <radical>beggar</radical>, doing his begging. But it doesn't work, nobody helps him. So, he just begins to <kanji>think</kanji>: Why am I in this situation? How could I have avoided it? How will I get out? Think, dammit, think!!
The <radical>meat</radical> radical and <kanji>meat</kanji> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
The <radical>self</radical> radical and <kanji>self</kanji> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
The <radical>color</radical> radical and <kanji>color</kanji> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
The <radical>go</radical> radical and the <kanji>go</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
The <radical>west</radical> radical and the <kanji>west</kanji> kanji are the same. Isn't that nice?
Our <radical>leader</radical> has a <radical>lip ring</radical>. Wait, our leader has a lip ring? <kanji>WHAT</kanji>??

The <radical>leader</radical> has a <radical>book</radical> all about the human <kanji>body</kanji>. Knowing about bodies is a privilege. One that only leaders get—it helps them control all their subjects, like you.

The <radical>leader</radical>'s <radical>key</radical> is the key that <kanji>make</kanji>s all the other keys. It's sort of like the one ring to rule them all, the one ring to bind them... except with keys.
You have a <radical>mouth</radical> full of two massive <radical>drop</radical>s and… <radical>treasure</radical>?! Upon closer inspection, they appear to form some sort of <kanji>diagram</kanji>!

You have a <radical>samurai</radical> with a <radical>flag</radical> on a <radical>stick</radical>. On his flag is the symbol 声, the kanji for <kanji>voice</kanji>. Why does he have that there? He feels like his Shogun isn't giving him and his fellow Samurai a voice, so he's brought a flag with the word "voice" written on it to protest.

There is someone wearing <radical>horns</radical>, holding a <radical>bow</radical>, and going down a <radical>slide</radical> held up by a <radical>stick</radical>. What type of person do you imagine? I'd say someone who's an immature boy. That would be your <kanji>younger brother</kanji>.

You're walking at night when you discover a <radical>lantern</radical> covered entirely in <radical>hair</radical>, making it a very strange <kanji>shape</kanji>. In fact, this is a <kanji>form</kanji> you'd never expect a lantern to take.

The <radical>ground</radical> is scattered with <radical>rice</radical>, which will cause the Predator to <kanji>come</kanji> because he loves rice. Then once he's gone, the <kanji>next</kanji> Predator will come to eat.

Plant a <radical>spirit</radical> in the <radical>dirt</radical> before you start your <kanji>company</kanji> and it will be successful. That's what all the great, old Japanese companies did back in the olden days. That's why companies like Mitsubishi have been around for hundreds of years. They planted a spirit in the dirt to help their company grow, and grow it did!
The <radical>angle</radical> radical and the <kanji>angle</kanji> kanji are the same!
The <radical>say</radical> radical and the <kanji>say</kanji> kanji are the same!

<radical>Fins</radical> decorate a <radical>hat</radical>, with (presumably fish) <radical>mouths</radical> stitched to it. Who wears strange hats like this? Turns out, the <kanji>valley</kanji> people are the ones who wear these. I'm talking about the "Valley Girls" of Los Angeles, California. They're into the crazy fashion, and they'll wear anything if it's deemed "cool" or something like that.
The radical <radical>run</radical> and the kanji <kanji>run</kanji> are exactly the same!

Someone on a <radical>scooter</radical> has an <radical>axe</radical>, and they're getting <kanji>near</kanji> to you really fast! Oh no, they're so <kanji>close</kanji> now, you need to get out of here!
The <radical>village</radical> you always think of first is your <kanji>hometown</kanji>.

The <radical>life</radical> radical is without the slide (as it sometimes is), but when you combine that with the <radical>winter</radical> radical, you have life during winter. What gives you life during the winter? It's the <kanji>wheat</kanji> you store away.

You have a wild <radical>viking</radical> <radical>child</radical> you have to take care of. He won't do anything but <kanji>study</kanji>, surprisingly. You can't get him to eat, use the bathroom, or anything else. He just wants to study.
You have a <radical>tree</radical> and another <radical>tree</radical>. You basically have yourself a <kanji>forest</kanji>!

What was the biggest <radical>hole</radical> in the <radical>construction</radical> of the world? The <kanji>sky</kanji>. If you think about it, the sky is like a big hole someone forgot to fill in. That's why this kanji also means <kanji>empty</kanji>! Makes sense — nothing is more empty than the sky.
The <radical>gold</radical> radical and the <kanji>gold</kanji> kanji are the same!
The radical for <radical>rain</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>rain</kanji> are the same thing.

The <radical>blue</radical> radical and the <kanji>blue</kanji> kanji are exactly the same.

Additionally, this can also mean <kanji>young</kanji>. You can remember this because young people have potential as limitless as the blue sky!

You plant your <radical>flowers</radical> in the light of the <radical>sun</radical> in the shape of a <radical>cross</radical>, but it's too hot—the sun is too strong—and you end up with <kanji>grass</kanji>. Flowers can't grow in these conditions.
For some reason, you are <radical>stand</radical>ing on the <radical>sun</radical>. It's obviously very hot, but the thing you notice most is the <kanji>sound</kanji> of you burning up.
The <radical>night</radical> radical and the <kanji>night</kanji> kanji are exactly the same.
When the <radical>moon</radical> is bright, it's easy to see that a <radical>pig</radical> is indeed a <kanji>pig</kanji>.

The <radical>axe</radical> radical and the <kanji>axe</kanji> kanji are exactly the same, with one minor difference. This kanji is also used as the <kanji>bread loaf counter</kanji>, probably because bread was so big and hard in the past that they had to use axes to slice them.
